content:
I managed to get 100% in 13:36.
Not only are there very large test cases, but there are a lot of them. When I finally got the right code, it still took a long time just to wait for it to check them all.
Something very strange happened in C++:
long long res = pow(100000007,2)
was giving me
10000001400000050 !!?!
I figured something with floating point rounding, but what a PITA.
I ended up using a loop to raise the root to the nth power, instead of pow().
Then it worked. So, for some reason, the Clash was only very difficult because of a C++ language problem. (Yes, I cast everything to long long before calculating; it really was using 100000007 as the input)
Like I said, checking takes a super long time even when your code is perfect; the high numbers are naturally justified to make people think, but I think you could leave out 4 of the 12 test cases, e.g., and it would not change much.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

Would be a nice solo puzzle,  but I think it is terrible for CoC. Some input test cases  are big, resulting timeout for any basic solution that one would come up in "Fastest" mode. Reverse mode would be even more annoying.
Yes _maybe_ from 9, 32 and 900 test cases, one would figure out that it is about powers. But test input = 999999874000003969 in a reverse mode CoC ???

Please, the goal of CoC is to make it fun for the players, not to annoy them.

your edges tests with big numbers are so big that you do a separate check for them in your solution, I can't see myself do it in a clash. Maybe, since there is a clash, you should stay with rather "small" numbers.
An other problem is that you don't test big flawed number. Anybody can do a check to return "perfect" if n > 10**6
The idea is cool though

I upvoted, but i hadn't gave the last approval because of the Upvote/Downvote.

I like the idea, not too hard, not too easy.

Then i also think that for reverse mode, you need more Perfect exemple.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It honestly looks like a pretty cool and easy CoC game.

I'm not sure I would gess it as a reverse.

Personnaly, I'm not a great fan of those puzzles with primes. You always have to first google and copy the Eratosthenes stuff or another algo that does the trick. Your contribution adds a twist to it, and therefore could be a good enough challenge but it doesn't look like much fun to me. You basically ask if the number is a power of a prime. Maybe that is why it has been rather downvoted so far. It is Coding, but it should be Game as well. I do not downvote, though, because what I just wrote is purely subjective and other players might see fun where I don't.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I see it a little too easy but you know, it is just good for a CoC, keep doing ;)

I modified it to be easier just now so perhaps you should rethink your approval!!!

Actually, it was kind of unreasonable to expect anyone to code it in 5 minutes but maybe it's not obvious why. Since the constraints are 10^18, you need to realize that normal prime factoring algorithms won't work and come up with a problem-specific solution (checking the square root up front, then only going to the cube root of 10^18). 

Even when you do that there was a big trap in the big square 4 factors test. (Before you had to check if a number was a PRIME power.) So you have to write another function to check if a number is prime. At minimum this is two decent sized functions + some cleverness, my experience with CoC is either 1 decent sized function and some cleverness, or just one of the last two.

Alternatively one can binary search for the pth powers + check low powers, this is also a decent amount of work, unless I'm missing something, I don't think this was easy at all.

The modification I made gets rid of the big trap so it should be better. Maybe I should add a warning about time complexity?

I changed the statement a bit: now you don't have to check if a number is a prime power, just a perfect power. This gets rid of the need for a prime check and simplifies the problem somewhat, making it easier to guess in reverse mode and easier to code in general. This changes the flavor text quite a bit, but the only test case that changes in my set is test 5. Therefore, there is less emphasis on trying to find a prime. Actually, the idea of this challenge is to create a situation where 'the Eratosthenes sieve or another algo' does not work and stop people who just jump to said idea (I will write more on this in response to python_programmerPP). IMO this problem requires a lot more thought than most, what do you think about the changes?
Thanks! Add two more perfect tests. (plus 2 validator)
You are right, I added another test case where n>10^6 and it is not perfect. As for the first comment, I do think the puzzle is a bit too hard

This problem was designed to give people who don't ever consider the time complexity of their code problems and benefit those who sit back and plan their algorithm a bit, if I take that away it becomes a lame 'factor this number' problem so I will not do that. I replaced the large numbers with ones that are easier to factor, though.
Hi, the number 10000001400000049 cannot be represented as a double, which is the reason for your problem. (pow returns a double). Instead you should just do multiplication of long longs.

This is a better way to do it if you can figure out how to take roots effectively. Your method won't work:
(python)
>>> 1000090002700027**(1/3)
100002.99999999994
Nice, then you found a simpler solution
